title: Update regarding OmniCorp Global
story_body:
# Critical Semiconductor Substrate Supplier Halts Shipments to Velocity Motors, Threatening Q2 Production Targets

Velocity Motors disclosed Tuesday that Taiwan-based Advanced Silicon Substrates Corporation has suspended deliveries of silicon carbide wafer substrates essential for the company's 800-volt inverter architecture, creating a cascading supply chain disruption that threatens to delay production of its flagship VX-7 electric crossover platform.

The substrate shortage directly impacts VELO's ability to manufacture its proprietary 300kW silicon carbide MOSFET power modules, which operate at junction temperatures up to 175 degrees Celsius and deliver 98.5 percent efficiency across the vehicle's dual-motor powertrain configuration. Without adequate substrate supply, Velocity Motors cannot maintain its targeted 12,000-unit monthly production cadence at its primary assembly facility.

The timing proves particularly problematic for OmniCorp Global, which holds a 23 percent equity stake in the electric vehicle manufacturer. OmniCorp's industrial automation division supplies the robotic cell assembly systems used in VELO's battery pack manufacturing line, creating operational interdependence between the two entities. The substrate shortage effectively idles OmniCorp's high-precision automated guided vehicles and delta-configuration pick-and-place robots installed at the VELO facility, reducing utilization rates on equipment valued at approximately $47 million.

Industry analysts note that silicon carbide substrate production operates on 120-day lead times, with current global capacity constrained to approximately 8 million wafers annually across qualified automotive-grade suppliers. Advanced Silicon Substrates' production halt stems from contamination issues in its chemical vapor deposition chambers, which maintain the critical 4H polytype crystal structure required for automotive-grade SiC devices.

Velocity Motors' VX-7 platform relies on 24 discrete SiC MOSFET modules per vehicle, each containing dies manufactured from 150mm substrates with epitaxial layer thickness specifications between 10-15 micrometers. The company's vertical integration strategy positioned these components as core intellectual property, preventing rapid supplier substitution.

OmniCorp's exposure extends beyond direct equity holdings. The company's automation equipment contracts include performance-based revenue sharing tied to VELO's production volumes, with penalty clauses triggered when monthly output falls below 9,500 units. Additionally, OmniCorp supplies the thermal management controllers for VELO's liquid-cooled battery systems, which maintain cell temperatures within the optimal 20-35 degree Celsius operating window.

The substrate supply interruption could persist for 90-120 days pending Advanced Silicon Substrates' clean room remediation and process requalification procedures.
